name: rectum cancer
definition: A colorectal cancer that is located_in the rectum. [url:http\://www.cancer.gov/dictionary?CdrID=529764]

evidence.efficacyEvidence: In a Phase I trial, the combination of Nelfinavir and radiotherapy resulted in median tumor cell density reduction from 24.3% at baseline to 9.2%, and tumor regression in 56% (5/9) of rectal cancer patients (PMID: 26861457).

references.title: Clinical Trial of Oral Nelfinavir before and during Radiation Therapy for Advanced Rectal Cancer.

evidence.efficacyEvidence: In a Phase I trial, Tarceva (erlotinib) and Linsitinib (OSI-906) combination treatment decreased Igf1r and Insr phosphorylation, resulted in a disease control rate of 51% (38/75), and partial response in 7% (5/75) of patients with advanced solid tumors, including a rectal cancer patient who remained on study for 36 weeks (PMID: 26831715).

references.title: Phase I Dose-Escalation Study of Linsitinib (OSI-906) and Erlotinib in Patients with Advanced Solid Tumors.

evidence.efficacyEvidence: Erbitux (cetuximab), as a monotherapy, is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with BRAF V600E (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab), as a monotherapy, is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with BRAF V600E (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 2 mutations (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 2 mutations (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 3 mutations (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 3 mutations (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 4 mutation (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with KRAS exon 4 mutations (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 2 mutations (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 2 mutations (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 4 mutations (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 4 mutations (NCCN.org).
Erbitux (cetuximab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 3 mutations (NCCN.org).
Vectibix (panitumumab) is not indicated for use in rectum cancer patients with NRAS exon 3 mutations (NCCN.org).
In a preclinical study, RMC-4550 inhibited growth of rectal cancer cells harboring KRAS G12C in 3D culture (PMID: 30104724).

references.title: RAS nucleotide cycling underlies the SHP2 phosphatase dependence of mutant BRAF-, NF1- and RAS-driven cancers.

evidence.efficacyEvidence: Herceptin (trastuzumab) in combination with Tykerb (lapatinib) is included in guidelines as second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic rectum cancer patients with ERBB2 amplification and wild-type KRAS and BRAF (NCCN.org).

molecularProfile.profileName: BRAF wild-type ERBB2 amp KRAS wild-type

evidence.efficacyEvidence: Herceptin (trastuzumab) in combination with Perjeta (pertuzumab) is included in guidelines as second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic rectum cancer patients with ERBB2 amplification and wild-type KRAS and BRAF (NCCN.org).

evidence.efficacyEvidence: Opdivo (nivolumab) is included in guidelines as a second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic rectum cancer patients with high microsatellite instability, MSI-H (NCCN.org).

Opdivo (nivolumab), in combination with Yervoy (ipilimumab), is included in guidelines as a second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic rectum cancer patients with high microsatellite instability, MSI-H (NCCN.org).
Keytruda (pembrolizumab) is included in guidelines as a second-line therapy for advanced or metastatic rectum cancer patients with high microsatellite instability, MSI-H (NCCN.org).
Lynch syndrome results from germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes including MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2, and is associated with increased risk of developing colorectal cancer (NCCN.org).
